Award.AwardTitle: Determining how Organic Matter is Stabilized using a Unique Set of Soil Samples from across the U.S.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Soil organic matter (SOM) is a critical linkage among many ecosystem services that sustain our society and life on Earth. It is the primary food source for microbes and the principal storehouse of water necessary for plant growth. SOM also stores nutrients for plants and absorbs pollutants that otherwise could contaminate food and water supplies. Soils also help regulate climate by storing carbon that would otherwise be released to the atmosphere and contribute to climate change. This project investigates processes in the soil that protect SOM from being completely consumed by microbes and conversely, processes that could increase its sensitivity to environmental changes. The researchers will also study how climate change and changes in how land is managed affect the amount and stability of SOM. The project involves a large number of researchers and laboratories in conducting a wide range of SOM analyses. It takes advantage of soil samples already collected by the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON), a major NSF investment in environmental monitoring that covers the entire United States. The samples will be preserved and the data that results from this project made fully public via the web.

The evolution of a new paradigm, where the primary controls on SOM dynamics are less dependent on molecular structure than on other soil and ecosystem properties, has created a knowledge gap in our ability to predict the response of SOM to environmental change. The relationships among shifting controls over different SOM stabilization mechanisms, ranging from distal factors operating at broad spatial scales (e.g., climate) to proximal controls operating at finer spatial scales (e.g., soil physicochemical properties), are poorly defined. Investigators will test the emerging paradigm by quantifying relationships between the dominant mechanisms of SOM stabilization and the scale of the ecosystem controls (i.e., fine-scale, proximal vs. broad-scale, distal) across a continental-scale system of soil types and ecological domains, utilizing soil samples collected during the construction of NEON. This project will be the first continental-scale assessment of SOM vulnerability and will yield new, predictive insights into controls on SOM stability across soil types, land-use types and environmental gradients. The results will significantly improve our understanding of SOM dynamics, a fundamental scientific advancement in its own right, while also enabling better representation of soils in ecosystem and coupled carbon-climate models. The project represents a new standard in open, community-oriented research, supporting participation by researchers from universities, government and non-government agencies. It will facilitate collaboration through major scientific networks that are increasingly necessary to conduct science at the scale needed to address the complex issues facing society. Graduate and undergraduate students will receive training in state-of-the-science methods of soil science by participating in this research, and insights derived from it will inform decisions by policymakers and resource managers concerned with carbon sequestration and ecosystem services.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Researchers Luke Nave (University of Michigan), Kate Heckman and Chris Swanston (USDA-Forest Service) have completed a 6-year investigation into the factors that control soil organic matter accumulation and loss. The investigators teamed with partners at Colorado University- Boulder, Oregon State University, the National Ecological Observatory Network, and Virginia Tech to complete one of the most thorough, detailed, cross-site soil comparisons ever conducted at the continental scale. The team used soils from 40 NEON sites, which were excavated during site construction activities but never planned to be saved for scientific purposes. Instead, the investigators preserved half of the samples from each site for sharing with the research community, to make efficient use of this precious scientific resource, and turned the other half into a set of groundbreaking papers and presentations. Those papers and presentations all focus in one way or another on soil organic matter, which is the foundation of soil productivity, water retention, fertility, pollutant removal- and ultimately the supply of food, fiber, and fuel for people. The study met all objectives outlined in its original funded proposal, and in the process of fulfilling its goals, it advanced the broader scientific understanding of soil organic matter, and the factors that influence its accumulation and loss. Key findings include:

  • Most soil organic matter takes centuries to millennia to accumulate, but much of it can be lost in a matter of years to decades with warming, changes in precipitation or land use
  • Soils across the U.S. differ widely in their vulnerability to organic matter loss; these differences are due to geographic variation in soil properties, climate and vegetation
  • Some soil organic matter losses are reversible; one of the most rapid and effective means to recovery is the reforestation of lands that have been abandoned from cultivation
  • The most important factors influencing soil organic matter amounts, accumulation and loss rates vary depending on the scale at which they are studied: at the continental scale, it’s climate; at the local scale, soil physical properties matter more

In order to share the intellectual merits of this project, its scientific results were communicated to the research community via peer-reviewed articles (4 published and 5 currently moving through peer review) and book chapters (1), 2 M.S. student theses, and 19 presentations at professional conferences.

The project also had significant broader impacts, mostly through training laboratory professionals, students, and post-graduate scientists in the methods of conducting soil organic matter research, analyzing data, and communicating results. Through these activities, the project provided training and professional advancement opportunities for:

  • Two laboratory technicians
  • One NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) student
  • Four graduate students (M.S. and Ph.D.)
  • Three postdoctoral researchers; two still in progress at collaborating institutions and one of whom was hired into a full-time permanent job as a soil scientist while helping to lead this project
  • External collaborators from 2 other research laboratories, who have conducted their own add-on studies by using samples that this project preserved and shared
